text: I don't be wrong running I would all
this is andrew jacobs reporting for the
New York Times gulo is one of the oldest
neighborhoods in Beijing it's great
Albert homes are anchored by a pair of
13th century towers whose drums and
giant bells once rang out the time of
day to the city's residents
the area remains one of the few parts of
the city that have not been plowed under
during the government's head long drive
to modernize the capital and maximize
profits and the redevelopment a valuable
land near the city center in fact gulo
has changed little through the centuries
its residents largely poor and it's
fabric still comprised of narrow alleys
called hutongs where much of life is
lived in public but all that is about to
change a government-backed redevelopment
plan will replace large swathes of the
ramshackle neighborhood with new shops
homes of the rich and a museum about the
history of time keeping many of the
existing residents who number in the
thousands will be relocated to high-rise
buildings on the outskirts of the city
although the government has yet to
release detailed other plans historians
fear the new gulo will resemble another
large-scale renewal project that
transformed Beijing's britty a beloved
shopping area Chapman just in time for
the 2008 Summer Olympics the results
critics say is a polished high-end
disney-esque tourist attraction that has
been swept clean of its original
buildings and is largely avoided by
Beijingers
historians warn that in its drive to
embrace the shining and new China is
sacrificing something more precious it's
hurly-burly street life it's
architectural heritage and its soul
